s.text: A fine goal, but the group has its work cut out for it--the most prominent Jewish woman this year pretty much fits those pejoratives to a T and the media didn't make her up: Monica Lewinsky.
A fine goal, but the group has its work cut out for it--the most prominent Jewish woman this year pretty much fits those pejoratives to a T and the media didn't make her up: Monica Lewinsky.

That Speakermania grips the papers this way shows they're a bit out of touch with what seems to be the point of last week's election results: the public doesn't care about what Washington cares about.
Christopher Cox as, albeit fading, still on the table, while the Los Angeles Times snags a late Sunday night interview with Cox in which he says he can't match Livingston's vote count.
The LAT reports on the activities of a women's group dedicated to fighting negative images of Jewish women in the media.
The NYT makes the point that Livingston, Cox and other members of the Republican House leadership used the Sunday chat shows to politick for their jobs, an unprecedented exercise.
